facts.text: Criminal Appeal 89 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal 89 of 1961. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 8, 1960 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1782 of 60 and Referred No. 125 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 8, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 1782 of 60 and Referred No. 125 of 1960,

facts.text: Sessions Judge, Etawah convicted Ram Singh under s. 302 I.P.C. and sentenced to death.

anchor.surface_text: confirming his conviction and sentence of death, under s. 302, I.P.C., by the Session Judge, Etawah.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed Ram Singh's appeal and confirmed conviction and sentence of death.

anchor.surface_text: against the order of the Allahabad High Court dismissing his appeal and confirming his conviction

facts.text: Ram Singh caused injuries to Sheo Sahai with a sword at about midnight on the night between June 14-15, 1960 while Sheo Sahai was sleeping in his cattle shed in village Bhadurpur Ghar.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case, in brief, is that due to enmity, the appellant caused injuries to Sheo Sahai, who was sleeping in his cattle shed in village Bhadurpur Ghar, with a sword at about mid- night on the night between June 14-15, 1960.

facts.text: Sheo Sahai died of the injuries received from Ram Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Sheo Sahai died of the injuries received.

facts.text: After incident, Ram Singh proceeded to Canal Distributory at some distance from village and had a bath there.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter proceeded to the Canal Distributory at some distance from the village and had a bath there.

facts.text: Ram Singh went to Police Station Ekdil, nine miles away, and lodged a report.

anchor.surface_text: Later on, he went to the Police Station, Ekdil, nine miles away and lodged a report.

facts.text: Ram Singh delivered the sword to police, which was found stained with human blood by Serologist.

anchor.surface_text: He delivered the sword which has been found by the Serologist to be stained with human blood.

facts.text: Ram Singh denied causing death of Sheo Sahai and alleged false accusation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied the allegation that he had caused the death of Sheo Sahai and alleged that he was falsely accused of the offence.

facts.text: Paley Singh informed Ram Singh about murder of Sheo Sahai and asked him to inform Police Station Ekdil orally.

anchor.surface_text: He also denied the other allegations for the prosecution. He alleged that one Paley Singh informed him about the murder of Sheo Sahai and asked him to go to the Police Station, Ekdil, and to inform the Station Officer orally about the murder.

facts.text: Ram Singh informed Station Officer orally about murder as per Paley Singh's instruction.

anchor.surface_text: He did accordingly.

facts.text: Ram Singh detained at Police Station till 11 a.m. next day and put in lock up.

anchor.surface_text: He was detained at the Police Station till 11 a.m., the next day and was then put up in the lock up.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector took Ram Singh's thumb impression forcibly on three papers without telling reason.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Inspector took his thumb impression forcibly on three papers, but did not tell him the reason.

facts.text: Courts below did not accept Ram Singh's version.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below rightly did not accept his version.

facts.text: There was enmity between Ram Singh and Sheo Sahai.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence led by the prosecution consisted of the evidence relating to motive,

facts.text: Ram Singh made extrajudicial confession to Ujagar Singh while having bath in Canal.

anchor.surface_text: to his extrajudicial confession to one Ujagar Singh when he was having a bath in the Canal,

facts.text: Ram Singh purchased the sword.

anchor.surface_text: to his purchasing the sword and to his delivering it at the police Station after he had dictated the report.

facts.text: Both courts below believed evidence about motive and purchase of sword by Ram Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Courts below rightly believed the evidence about the motive and purchase of the sword by the appellant.

facts.text: Sessions Judge believed Ujagar Singh and acted on extrajudicial confession.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge believed Ujagar Singh and acted on the extra-judicial confession made by the appellant to him.

facts.text: High Court did not rely on extrajudicial confession to Ujagar Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, did not rely on this extra-judicial confession.

facts.text: High Court relied on statements in Ram Singh's report at PS, motive, purchase of sword to confirm conviction.

anchor.surface_text: It relied on certain statements made by the appellant in his report dictated at the Police Station and considered those facts together with the motive and the evidence about the purchase of the sword sufficient to confirm the appellants conviction and sentence.

facts.text: Ajit Singh (PW5) deposed about purchase of cycle from Sheo Sahai by Ram Singh and dispute over Rs.10/- as deal cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: Ajit Singh, P.W., 5 deposed about the purchase of the cycle and about a dispute taking place between Sheo Sahai and the appellant on account of the latters demanding the return of Rs. 10/- which had been paid towards the sale price as the balance of the sale price had not been paid and the deal was cancelled by Sheo Sahai in accordance with the oral contract.

facts.text: No enmity between Ajit Singh and Ram Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Ajit Singh bears no enmity with the appellant.

facts.text: None of prosecution witnesses alleged to bear enmity with Ram Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, none of the prosecution witnesses is alleged to bear enmity with the appellant.

facts.text: Paley Singh PW2 and Baij Nath PW4 deposed about dispute during game of cards on June 12, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Paley Singh, P.W. 2, and Baij Nath P.W. 4, depose about the dispute during the game of cards played on June 12, 1960.

facts.text: Kehar Singh PW3 deposed about selling sword to Ram Singh on June 13, 1960; receipt found on Ram Singh after arrest.

anchor.surface_text: Kehar Singh P.W.3. deposed about the selling of a sword to the appellant on June 13, 1960. A receipt about the sale was found on the person of the appellant when he was searched after his arrest.

facts.text: Ram Singh deposited sword at Police Station, deposed by Madho Ram PW12 and Sri Kishan Singh SO PW16.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants depositing the sword at the Police Station is deposed by Madho Ram P.W. 12, and by Sri Kishan Singh, Station Officer, Ekdil, W. 16 , in whose presence the appellant had dictated the report.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds no need to rely on admissions in report as independent evidence exists.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider it necessary to decide whether any portion of the report dictated by the appellant at the Police Station is admissible or not in evidence, as there is good independent evidence

facts.text: Supreme Court holds High Court erred in rejecting Ujagar Singh's statement about confession.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that Ujagar Singhs statement about the appellants confessing to him that he had murdered Sheo Sahai has been erroneously rejected by the High Court.

facts.text: Ujagar Singh was protecting crop from neel gais in field in middle of June.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that Ujagar Singh was on the field, according to his statement, for protecting the crop from the depradations of neel gais.

facts.text: Fields had chari and sugar-cane crop at the time.

anchor.surface_text: especially when the learned Judges believed, and there was evidence about it, that the fields had chari and sugarcane crop at the time.

facts.text: No enmity between Ujagar Singh and Ram Singh.

anchor.surface_text: There is no enmity between Ujagar Singh and the appellant and therefore no good reasons existed for Ujagar Singh to state falsely.

facts.text: Ram Singh had no blood stains on person or clothes when at PS per Sub-Inspector Kishan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It is not stated by sub- Inspector Kishan Singh, nor it is alleged that the appellant had on his person or on his clothes blood stains when he presented himself at the Police Station.

facts.text: Canal runs beside Ujagar Singh's field.

anchor.surface_text: The Canal runs beside Ujagar Singhs field.

facts.text: Ujagar Singh went to village at about 5 a.m. and told people about confession.

anchor.surface_text: Ujagar Singh went to the village at about 5 a.m., and them told the people of what he had been told by the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court convicts Ram Singh under s.302 IPC and upholds death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that he has been rightly convicted of the offence under s. 302, P.C., and has been awarded the proper sentence.
Appeal by special leave
under s. 302, I.P.C., by the Session Judge, Etawah.

holdings.text: The Courts below rightly did not accept his version.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below rightly did not accept his version.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant adduced no evidence in support of his statement.

holdings.text: Both the Courts below rightly believed the evidence about the motive and purchase of the sword by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Courts below rightly believed the evidence about the motive and purchase of the sword by the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution witnesses deposed reliably with no enmity alleged against appellant.

holdings.text: We do not consider it necessary to decide whether any portion of the report dictated by the appellant at the Police Station is admissible or not in evidence, as there is good independent evidence with respect to the four matters.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider it necessary to decide whether any portion of the report dictated by the appellant at the Police Station is admissible or not in evidence, as there is good independent evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Independent witness testimony covers cycle purchase, quarrel, sword purchase, and deposit.

holdings.text: It is therefore not necessary to rely on the admissions of the appellant in the report with respect to these facts deposed to by the various witnesses whose testimony has been rightly accepted.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore not necessary to rely on the admissions of the appellant in the report with respect to these facts deposed to by the various witnesses whose testimony has been rightly accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witnesses like Ajit Singh PW5, Paley Singh PW2, Baij Nath PW4, Kehar Singh PW3, Madho Ram PW12, Sri Kishan Singh PW16 provide direct evidence.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that Ujagar Singhs statement about the appellants confessing to him that he had murdered Sheo Sahai has been erroneously rejected by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that Ujagar Singhs statement about the appellants confessing to him that he had murdered Sheo Sahai has been erroneously rejected by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court reasoning inconsistent on crop height and likelihood; Sessions Judge reasons sound; no enmity.

holdings.text: Extra-judicial confessions are not usually considered with favour but that does not mean that such a confession coming from a person who has no reason to state falsely and to whom it is made in circumstances which tend to support his statement, should not be believed.

anchor.surface_text: Extra-judicial confessions are not usually considered with favour but that does not mean that such a confession coming from a person who has no reason to state falsely and to whom it is made in circumstances which tend to support his statement, should not be believed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General evidentiary rule applied; Ujagar Singh had no reason to lie falsely; circumstances like bath, canal location support.

holdings.text: The extra-judicial confession of the appellant to Ujagar Singh finds ample support from the facts that the appellant did purchase a sword a day before, that very sword was found to be stained with human blood shortly after the murder and that sword was handed over by the appellant himself to the Police Officer at the Police Station.

anchor.surface_text: The extra- judicial confession of the appellant to Ujagar Singh finds ample support from the facts that the appellant did purchase a sword a day before, that very sword was found to be stained with human blood shortly after the murder and that sword was handed over by the appellant himself to the Police Officer at the Police Station.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances of motive, weapon purchase, blood stains, and conduct corroborate confession.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that he has been rightly convicted of the offence under s. 302, P.C., and has been awarded the proper sentence.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that he has been rightly convicted of the offence under s. 302, P.C., and has been awarded the proper sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enmity motive, sword purchase and delivery stained with human blood, and corroborated extra-judicial confession fully prove guilt beyond doubt.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that he has been rightly companyvicted of the offence under s. 302, P.C., and has been awarded the proper sentence.

outcome.relief_summary: Conviction under s. 302 IPC and death sentence confirmed as proper; no relief to appellant
